climada.hazard.centroids package¶

climada.hazard.centroids.base module¶

climada.hazard.centroids.base.FILE_EXT = {'.csv': 'CSV', '.mat': 'MAT', '.xls': 'XLS', '.xlsx': 'XLS'}¶

Supported files format to read from

class climada.hazard.centroids.base.Centroids(file_name='', description='')[source]¶

Bases: object

Definition of the hazard coordinates.

tag¶

information about the source

Type:Tag
coord¶

2d array with lat in first column and lon in second. “lat” and “lon” are descriptors of the latitude and longitude respectively.

Type:np.array
id¶

an id for each centroid

Type:np.array
region_id¶

region id for each centroid (when defined)

Type:np.array, optional
name¶

name of centroids (e.g. country, region)

Type:str, optional
resolution¶

If coord is a regular grid, then a tuple of the form (res_lat, res_lon) can be set. Uses the same units as the coord attribute.

Type:float tuple, optional
__init__(file_name='', description='')[source]¶

Fill values from file, if provided.

Parameters:
  • file_name (str, optional) – name of the source file
  • description (str, optional) – description of the source data
Raises:

ValueError

Examples

Fill centroids attributes by hand:

>>> centr = Centroids()
>>> centr.coord = np.array([[0,-1], [0, -2]])
>>> ...

Read centroids from file:

>>> centr = Centroids(HAZ_DEMO_MAT, 'Centroids demo')
clear()[source]¶

Reinitialize attributes.

check()[source]¶

Check instance attributes. Ids are unique.

Raises:ValueError
read(files, descriptions='', var_names=None)[source]¶

Read and check centroids.

Parameters:
  • files (str or list(str)) – absolute file name(s) or folder name containing the files to read
  • descriptions (str or list(str), optional) – one description of the data or a description of each data file
  • var_names (dict or list(dict), default) – name of the variables in the file (default: check def_source_vars() function)
Raises:

TypeError, ValueError
append(centroids, set_uni_id=True)[source]¶

Append centroids values with NEW points. Id is perserved if not present in current centroids. Otherwise, a new id is provided.

Parameters:
  • centroids (Centroids) – Centroids instance to append
  • set_uni_id (bool, optional) – set centroids.id to unique values
Returns:

array of size centroids with True in the new

elements (which have been put at the end of self)
Return type:

np.array(bool))
select(reg_id)[source]¶

Get copy new instance with all the attributs in given region

Parameters:reg_id (int or list) – regions to select
Returns:Centroids
plot(**kwargs)[source]¶

Plot centroids points over earth.

Parameters:kwargs (optional) – arguments for scatter matplotlib function
Returns:matplotlib.figure.Figure, matplotlib.axes._subplots.AxesSubplot
set_dist_coast()[source]¶

Add dist_coast attribute: distance to coast in km for each centroids. No distinction between sea and land centroids.

set_area_per_centroid()[source]¶

If the centroids are on a regular grid and have their resolution set, set the area_per_centroid attribute, assuming degrees for the points and km2 for the area.

set_on_land()[source]¶

Add the on_land attribute, i.e. if a centroid is on land.

get_nearest_id(lat, lon)[source]¶

Get id of nearest centroid coordinate. Not thought to be called recursively!

Parameters:
  • lat (float) – latitude
  • lon (float) – longitude
Returns:

int
set_region_id()[source]¶

Set the region_id to the adm0 ISO_N3 (country) code as indicated by natural earth data. Currently simply iterates over all countries in extent given by Centroids instance. Not terribly efficient; could implement a raster burn method if centroids lie on regular grid. Could also employ parallelization.

Take heed: the natural earth dataset has errors and misclassifies, among others, Norway, Somaliland, and Kosovo, using -99 instead of their assigned codes. Have a look at the natural earth shapefiles and attribute tables.

remove_duplicate_coord()[source]¶

Checks whether there are duplicate coordinates and removes the du- plicates. The first appearance of the coordinates is left untouched while all duplicates later in the array are removed.

resolution

Returns a tuple of the resolution in the same unit as the coords.

lat¶

Get latitude from coord array

lon¶

Get longitude from coord array

size¶

Get count of centroids

extent¶

Gets geographical extent as tuple

Returns:(min_lon, max_lon, min_lat, max_lat)
Return type:extent (tuple, optional)
shape_grid¶

If the centroids lie on a regular grid, return its shape as a tuple of the form (n_lat, n_lon), that is, (height, width)

static get_sup_file_format()[source]¶

Returns:list(str)

Returns:dictionary with variable names
